course.subject: ECON
course.name: Econometrics for Cross-Section and Panel Data
course.description: This course introduces students to advanced econometric tools for analyzing cross section and panel data.  These tools are useful in areas such as industrial organization, corporate finance, labor and public economics.  Topics include: instrumental variable estimation; panel data; discrete choice models; censored and truncated dependent variables; duration models.

reviews.comment_content:
Review of Linear Regression
Basics about Causal Inference
RCT and Machine Learning
------------------------------------
Instrumental Variable

The content is simple but essential in the ECON field. Highly recommend taking this course for fundamental knowledge in data analysis research. Some R applications are taught for empirical stufffff. The professor actually planned to cover more content but he was kind of behind the schedule.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Feng is one of the best professors in ECON courses. Even if you are not really good at econometrics I believe by taking his course you can find yourself understanding the rationale and concepts. Though I am not really good at math and do not get a good grade in this course, I would say it is worth taking this course under Professor Feng's teaching haha.
He always goes through the concept clearly and simply so I guess the pace might be too slow for skilled students but hahaha really suitable for me la.
(In my really personal opinion, if you are not good at math but would like to challenge and learn more in econometrics I really recommend you to enroll in this course, forget about the grade you can really learn something and get confidence!!)
reviews.comment_grading:
Problem Set *3 (5% each)
Midterm Exam (35%)
Final Exam (50%)

I found the class with mainly mainland students, the grading might be very steep since the average is sky-high lol. (I have never seen a final exam for a 4-level course with an average of 87/100. Pretty ridiculous huh.)
It seems like students taking this course are pretty good at math and econometrics. Might also be due to the small number of students enrolled in this course (33) and the final exam is not that difficult as well.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is small with only three problem sets.

reviews.author: Peter Lau
reviews.comment_content:
This course is an advanced econometric course focusing on cross-sectional and panel data. The techniques introduced are extremely useful for building a robust regressional model for economic analysis.

Key topics covered:
1. LLN, CLT, Theory of Linear Regression
2. Correlation and Causality
3. Experiment and Quasi Experiment
4. Panel Data
5. Instrumental Variables
6. Maximum Likelihood Estimator
7. Limited Dependent Variables
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Lu explained all the concepts very clearly in class. He also helped us to print out all the notes so we could save lots of printing budgets. Attendance was not required but some derivations discussed in class (not in the notes) might be tested in the exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Three problems sets (15%, each 5%)
2. Mid-term (35%)
3. Final Exam (50%)

You can bring a cheatsheet to exam. Remember to copy a) every derivation discussed (including those that are not in the notes but are discussed in class) and b) answers of after-chapter exercise.

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: As a 4-credit course, the workload is VERY LOW. You only need to work on three problem sets. For exams, reviewing all the notes and doing after-chapter exercise are good enough to secure A range.
